article: Money was a constant source of tension and stress when I was growing up. My parents were _ , well-educated and hard-working, but they lived from paycheck to paycheck. When I was 13, they split up. Then my mom _ to raise three kids, often relying on free lunch tickets and food stamps. As my mother _ retirement age, she was filled with _ over the fact that she hadn't saved enough for her golden retirement years, _ she often sighed. My father had always been _ to work--we had always _ he'd work less and spend more time with us _ . But he is just a workaholic . My parents were trying so hard to make ends meet, so I couldn't become a _ on them. As a result, I dropped out of college and spent the next couple of years drifting from one minimum wage job to another. I gave away my broken-down car, went to work on foot, reduced my _ by sharing a one-bedroom apartment with three other women, and got free food during Happy Hour at our local bar. I learned to do whatever it took to _ . One night, while I was working at a donut shop and _ coffee for a homeless customer, I _ that I was one paycheck away from being homeless myself. That was my wake-up _ . Motivated by fear of an uncertain _ , I opened the Yellow Pages , _ professional dog trainers and negotiated an unpaid apprenticeship . Less than a year later, I was _ by a dog trainer, and I loved the work. A couple of years later, I started my own dog-training school, which luckily turned out to be _ . My efforts paid off. Though I didn't have rich parents to rely on, I discovered the power of asking for what I want.
